items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This flood alert has been issued as strong winds are expected to cause overtopping waves and spray along the coast. Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Flooding of coastal roads, promenades and coastal footpaths is expected between 9:00 AM and 7:00 PM on Thursday 17/11/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. The area of concern is expected to be at Sandsend between 10:00am and 1:30pm on 17/11/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:00am, 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.message: Thursday's tide from 12:00am to 2:30am and 9:00am to 7:00pm on 17/11/2022 is higher than normal due to winds and large waves. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary. Further rainfall over the coming days will mean river levels are likely to fluctuate. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 17/11/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

The River Uck is high and rising. Over the last day, 20mm of rain has been recorded at Buxted. Flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. Areas in Uckfield most at risk include The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage & Bell Walk. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast and may close our flood gate in the supermarket car park in Uckfield town centre to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 09:00 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Thursday evening. River levels could end up similar to the peaks of last week. Riverside properties in Buxted are encouraged to install flood protection products if you have them and take steps to reduce the impact of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected from 9pm on Wednesday 16 November and will continue overnight. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Teise particularly in Lamberhurst. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 8 hours until 1am on Thursday 17 November. We expect river levels to remain high overnight.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 17 November, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high and rising. Over the last day 30mm of rain has been recorded at Cowfold. Flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon (16/11/2022) into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is very high and rising. In the last 48 hours, more than half a months rain (70mm) has been recorded at Knighton. By 04:00 (17/11/2022), the river will flood gardens in Alverstone and Langbridge, and the main road at Alverstone. At Sandown, Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will continue to flood, and levels will be high at Sandown Bridge, the sewage treatment plant and Fort Holiday Park. By 02:00 (17/11/2022), gardens will flood in Nicholas Close. Property flooding is a possibility throughout the Eastern Yar. We will issue a Flood Warning if we think this will occur. Dry weather is expected for the rest of the night. The river will peak at Alverstone at around 16:00 (17/11/2022), and on Thursday night at Sandown. We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to help reduce water levels across Brading Marshes. We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please take action now to ensure you can protect your property. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday 17/11/2022 or sooner if required.

Flood water could approach properties at Slaugham Place near Old Hall on Brantridge Lane, Bridge Cottage at Sheffield Park, Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, Freshfield Mill Farm, Freshmill and Millers Cottages on Sloop Lane. Some roads including Mill Road and Church Road may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Barcombe. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. The Anchor Inn is expected to flood and water could approach properties at Barcombe Mills. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 17:00 17/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels could end up similar to the peaks of last week. Flood water will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from 15:00 Wednesday afternoon (16/11/22) into the early hours of Thursday morning. The Western Rother will rise again in all locations, bringing a risk of flooding. Property flooding is likely at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth from 03:00 17/11/2022, but also possible between Liss and Midhurst. Thursday, Friday and Saturday should be mostly dry. But river levels in Fittleworth will not begin to fall until Thursday evening (17/11/22). Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. Please plan to avoid driving through roads prone to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

The Langney Haven is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, nearly half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Folkington. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 21:00 16/11/2022 minor flooding could affect gardens of properties at Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park will also be affected. River levels could end up similar to the peaks seen last week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles Gate to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high and rising. In the last 36 hours 20mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Wednesday afternoon and evening.  From 19:00 16/11/2022 flooding could affect fields, rural roads and a small number of properties in Crowhurst. Potentially including Crowhurst Recreation Ground, riverside properties on Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. From 02:00 17/11/2022 water may also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Wednesday's rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall in Crowhurst by 10:00 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until the weekend. River levels could end up higher than the peaks of last week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

The River Arun is high and rising. In the last 36 hours, nearly half a month's rain (36mm) has been recorded at Itchingfield. This is a lot in a short period. From 19:00 16/11/2022 flooding could affect gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and fields behind Arunside. From 23:00 16/11/2022 flood water will affect fields and gardens of isolated mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay, including the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst. From 02:00 17/11/2022 properties at Pallingham Lock could be affected. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected Wednesday evening. Thursday and Friday are forecast to be dry. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 17/11/2022 in Horsham and Friday at Pallingham Quay. The River Arun will be higher than normal until the weekend. River levels could end up higher than last week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

The River Lox is high and rising. Over the last day 20mm of rain has been recorded at Chiddingfold. Flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens along the length of the river Lox and approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood and isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold. Flood water may also affect riverside properties on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Please operate private water control structures to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high and rising. Over the last day, 30mm of rain has been recorded at Westergate. Flooding could affect a small number of riverside properties in Marshall Close, and along Lake Lane. Barnham Road near the Trading Post and the road junction of Barnham Lane and Lake Lane could be affected by flood water. Flooding will affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as possibly parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river levels should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed if you have them. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

items.message:
Flooding is possible from late this afternoon Wednesday 16 November and into the early hours of Thursday morning. 

Persistent rain is forecast this afternoon and evening Wednesday 16 November, followed by heavy showers overnight. Some of this rain could be heavy, especially over high ground. 

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers from late this afternoon and into the early hours of Thursday morning.  

We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected. Further heavy showers are forecast over the next few days.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 10am Thursday morning, or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels will rise on the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester from 05:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
Further rainfall is forecast this evening.
River levels will rise at the Hooke, Maiden Newton gauge.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.  Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.message: River levels are rising steadily on the Upper Dorset Stour, Shreen Water. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Stour, Shreen Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton. Flooding is possible at tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton from 06:00 PM on 15/11/2022. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon. River levels are forecast to rise further at the Colesbrook, Gillingham Le Neubourg Way, Hammoon, Lodden Bridge, Milton on Stour gauge. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are stable at the Brokenborough, Fosseway and Great Somerford but will rise again on Wednesday evening in response to the forecast rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge with river levels peaking between 7am and 10am on Thursday 17th Novemner.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated on the morning of Thursday 17th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Middle Dorset Stour due to the rainfall in the last 36hours. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Hammoon, Bere Marsh, Stourpaine, Durweston and Lower Blandford St Mary. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon which may lead to further river rises. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Consider activating any property flood protection products. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Plan driving routes to avoid the Hammoon road as the gates are locked closed as the road has been affected by flooding. This message will be updated 11:00 AM on the 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Stour and Iwerne at Stourpaine
items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Middle Dorset Stour due to the rainfall in the last 36hours. Areas most at risk include Havelins and the SPFA sports pavilion areas in Stourpaine. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon which may lead to further river rises. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Consider activating any property flood protection products. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Consider putting your flood plan into action. This message will be updated by 12:00 Noon on 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday 17/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible during the afternoon of Wednesday 16th November into Thursday Morning. 
 
Following heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours catchments in this area remain wet and sensitive to any further rainfall.

During Wednesday afternoon, a further low-pressure system will affect this area, bringing heavy rain and strong winds.  Up to 35mm of rainfall forecast for some locations. 
 
River levels are forecast to rise in response. The highest levels are forecast during Wednesday night into Thursday morning.  The main areas of concern are low lying land and roads close to the river.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor river levels and issue Flood Warnings if required.  Trash screens and blockages have been cleared in this area. This message will be updated on Thursday morning (17/11/22) or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This flood alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely on Thursday 17/11/2022 between 12:00pm and throughout the afternoon and evening. Areas most at risk include Marine Royal Albert Drive and Sandside in Scarborough, and exposed coastal roads and promenades where the combination of wave action and spray is expected to cause hazardous conditions. Please be careful along beaches and exposed coastal areas as waves and spray may be unpredictable. We continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 11:00am on 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening Wednesday 16 November and into the early hours of Thursday morning. 

Persistent rain is forecast this afternoon and evening Wednesday 16 November, followed by heavy showers overnight. Some of this rain could be heavy, especially over high ground. 

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 5pm this evening and into the early hours of Thursday morning.  

We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected. Further heavy showers are forecast over the next few days.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 10am Thursday morning, or earlier if the situation changes.

The Western Rother is high and rising. In the last 36 hours, nearly half a month's rain (47mm) has been recorded at Iping. From 18:00 Wednesday (16/11/2022) flooding will be extensive in fields. Flood water will affect Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. The B2138 Lower Street road over the river at Fittleworth could be impassable. The river rise should slow down this evening, however a further 20-30mm of rain is expected between 15:00 Wednesday and 04:00 Thursday (17/11/2022). The Western Rother will rise again Thursday morning. Thursday and Friday are forecast to be dry. The river might not begin to fall until the early hours of Friday, and will be higher than normal until next week. River levels could end up higher than the peaks of last week. Some roads, including the B2138 through Fittleworth, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

River levels are rising on the River Nadder due to heavy rainfall.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening which will cause river levels to rise again.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Nadder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Nadder and tributaries between Donhead St Mary and Salisbury.
Flooding is possible at the River Nadder and tributaries between Donhead St Mary and Salisbury from 06:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening.
River levels are rising at the Tisbury gauge.
We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high, following 36mm of rain in the last 36 hours. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Wednesday afternoon and evening. From 23:00 on Wednesday (16/11/2022) minor flooding could affect locations near Slaughter Bridge on Coolham Road, as well as isolated farm buildings, fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield. It is possible water may approach gardens of Church Close, Shipley. The rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday (17/11/2022), leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 on 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels could end up higher than peaks of the last week. Some roads, including Coolham Road at Slaughter Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 17/11/2022.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: River Medway between Forest Row and Penshurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of property, roads and low-lying land is expected between 9pm this evening, Wednesday 16 November, and 9am tomorrow, Thursday 17 November 2022. We expect flooding to affect properties on and around Beech Green Lane and Rogues Hill, near the river Medway at Hartfield.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours until 11pm on 16 November. We expect river levels to remain high overnight.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Medway.
Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and remain aware in case the situation changes. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 17 November or as the situation changes.

Rainfall is expected throughout the day tomorrow (17/1//2022) resulting in rising river levels.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message: Levels are forecast to rise at Bruton Dam as a result of this evenings rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads, farmland and property is possible Wednesday evening,16/11/22 and into the early hours of Thursday.  Areas most at risk are the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road.  Overtopping is possible from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington - Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion
items.message: This flood warning has been issued as strong winds are expected to cause overtopping waves and spray along the coast in Bridlington. Areas most at risk include the north side of the dock area, properties on Harbour Road and the Floral Pavilion. Flooding is expected between 9:00 AM and 7:00 PM on Thursday 17/11/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Lower Dorset Stour due to heavy rainfall.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening which will cause river levels to rise again.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch from 08:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
Further rainfall is forecast this evening.
River levels are rising at the Blandford, Throop, Wimborne A31 gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The water levels in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River are high and rising. In the last 48 hours half a months rain (45mm) was recorded at Romsey. This is a large amount of rain in a short period of time. From 23:30 this evening (16/11/22), the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the mill building at East Wellow. Further rain is forecast over the next 8 hours. We expect the river will rise at least until 10:00 Thursday (17/11/22). Although water levels will be much higher than normal, property flooding is not currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 10:00 on 17/11/2022 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

The water level in the West Brook at Bridge Road is rising rapidly increasing by 50cm in the last hour. In the last 4 hours 30mm of rain has been recorded in Havant. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. Due to the intensity of the rain which has already fallen, from 20:15 this evening (16/11/22) Bridge Road will be flooding. Water in the river will also rise to bank full over the next 30 minutes and it may also come out of bank. This will increase flood depths in the road and at the riverside car park but flooding of property directly from the river is not expected. The heaviest rain has now cleared the area. Water levels will remain very high over the next couple of hours but should fall by 22:00. To ensure a free flow of water down the river, we drained Emsworth Mill Pond earlier today. We are also keeping debris screens at Bridge Road clear of blockages. As a precautionary measure, we would encourage residents with flood protection products to install them now. This Flood Alert will be updated at 10:00 on 17/11/22.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected overnight at Tonbridge playing fields, town centre car parks, Postern Lane through to Tudeley, East Peckham and The Lees at Yalding. Further heavy rain is forecast later this evening on Wednesday 16 November and will clear around 1am. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday 17 November.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Thursday 17 November or as the situation changes.

The Powdermill Stream is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, 35mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill, which is a lot in a short period. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 22:00 16/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads and a small number of riverside properties in Crowhurst; on Forewood Lane and properties between The Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 10:00 17/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels will end up higher than the peaks of last week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 17/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of property, roads and low-lying land is expected 4am tomorrow, Thursday 17 November. We expect flooding to affect properties around Pound Lane and Magpie Hall Road. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the morning of Thursday 17 November. 

Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater. 

This message will be updated by 11am on 17 November, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Ardingly. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 23:00 16/11/2022 flood water will affect properties of Freshfield Mill Farm, Freshmill and Millers Cottages on Sloop Lane and Bridge Cottage, Sheffield Park. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will be affected and potentially impassable. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels could end up higher than the peaks of last week. Some roads including Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding suggested in this message. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy and persistent rainfall throughout today. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible today, 16/11/2022 and through until Thursday. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high tonight and throughout Thursday 17/11/2022, particularly around Willersley Avenue. River levels are expected to remain high, though property flooding is not currently expected. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing trash screens across the catchment. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lodsbridge to Shopham Bridge on the Western Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (65mm) has been recorded at Iping. Another 10mm of rain is forecast Wednesday evening. From 03:00 17/11/2022 flood water will affect fields, gardens, rural roads and properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham. Flood water could affect properties and the A285 at Coultershaw Bridge, near Petworth. Properties on the Lod could also be affected, including those near Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane, and at Halfway Bridge. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river might not begin to fall until 22:00 17/11/2022, and will be higher than normal until the weekend. River levels will end up higher than the peaks of Wednesday morning. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Lodsbridge, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

The water level in the Lukely Brook is high and rising. In the last 6 hours, 26mm of rain has fallen at Carisbrooke. This is in addition to the prolonged and heavy rainfall experienced over the last few weeks. The river will already be bank full in most locations and could come out of bank from Old Westminster Lane to Towngate Bridge. Both surface water and the river could flood into the road and affect the bottom of Castle Street. The heaviest rain has now cleared the area, and only scattered showers are forecast overnight. Water levels will remain high for the next couple of hours before they begin to fall at 00:00 (17/11/22). Our operational contractors are making sure the river is kept free of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid flooded riverside footpaths. We would encourage residents living nearest the river to take action to protect their property. This Flood Alert will be updated at 11:00 on 17/11/22 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

items.description: Carisbrooke and Hunny Hill on the Lukely Brook
items.message: The water level in the Lukely Brook at Carisbrooke is high and rising. In the last 6 hours heavy rain has been recorded at Carisbrooke (26mm). This is a large volume in a short period of time. From now, the Aquatics Centre at Vicarage Walk near Foxes Road will also flood. Water levels will be very high at Caesars Road and Old Westminster Lane, and the river could be out of bank, flooding roads and parked cars. Most of the rain has now cleared the area which means that water levels should begin to fall early tomorrow morning (17/11/2022). Our operational contractors are out in the area, making sure the river is kept free of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection now. This Flood Warning will be updated by 11:00 on 17/11/2022.

items.description: Crosslands Drive and West Leigh, Havant, on the Lavant Stream
items.message: The water level in the Lavant Stream at Crosslands Drive is high and rising rapidly. In the last 6 hours, heavy and intense rain has fallen, with 35mm recorded at Walderton. This is a significant amount in a short period of time. From 22:00 this evening (16/11/22), property nearest to the river at Crosslands Drive and New Lane could flood. The heaviest rain has now cleared the area. Showery conditions will continue until later this evening and into the early hours of tomorrow morning. The river will peak at 02:00 (17/11/22). Our operational staff are en route to site and will clear the debris screen at Crossland Drive. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection now. If you wish to view it, our river level data at Crossland Drive is displayed on www.gov.uk. This Flood Warning will be updated by 10:00 17/11/22.

The water level in the River Lymington at Brockenhurst is high and rising. In the last 8 hours, 24mm of rain has been recorded in Brockenhurst. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. From 23:30 on 16/11/2022, the river will be much higher than normal and drainage ditches through the New Forest will be flooding land and roads. It will be bank full as it flows through Martins Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 10 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. Lighter rain is forecast over the next 3 hours which means that the river will remain high until at least 08:00 on 17/11/2022 before water levels fall. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Watersplashes will deepen over the next 24 hours. Do not drive through floodwater. This Flood Alert will be updated at 12:00 on 17/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (50mm) has been recorded at Ardingly. From 05:00 17/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens and affect properties at Bridge Cottage and Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield. Rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 17/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until Friday morning. River levels could end up similar to those seen in March 2020. Riverside properties at Dean's Water Mill and Lindfield Bridge are encouraged to install flood protection products if you have them and take steps to reduce the impact of flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 17/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high and rising. In the last 2 days, more than half a month's rain (78mm) has been recorded at Ardingly. From 04:00 17/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens and affect properties at Slaugham Place, near Old Hall on Brantridge Lane. Only very small amounts of rain are forecast over the next 2 days. The river should begin to fall by Thursday afternoon and should return to normal from Friday. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Riverside properties are encouraged to install flood protection products if you have them and take steps to reduce the impact of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: Rivers Eden and Eden Brook from Crowhurst and Blindley Heath to Penshurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of low lying property, roads and low lying land is expected from 3.30am this morning, Thursday 17 November 2022. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for properties around Haxted Mill and Haxted Road and properties along the River Eden and Eden Brook around Haxted Mill, Edenbridge and Hever.  Further light rainfall is forecast until midday on 17 November 2022. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the morning.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. This message will be updated by 11am on 17 November 2022, or as the situation changes
